reviewText: Frederick OBrien's marvelous book of the same title was a best seller when it was published in 1919.  It was record of the author's stay in the Marquesas at the turn of the 18/19 century and contains priceless, fascinating photos.The major part of the movie is the story of a degenerate white who washes up on an as yet "unspoiled" island, protrayed to be like the garden of Eden.  His life and soul are restored but at some point he succumbs to greed  and the result is that paradise comes to an end.In regards to the book the movie story is bogus.  Furthermore, the book does not contain the anti-white racist doggeral in the movie.  The book instead contains many fascinating stories about the Marquesas at the time, of both the natives and the French residents.  It also has a more measured history of both the darker side and the pleasant side of this paradise.  On the dark side, cannibalism had become almost casual in the later stages of aboriginal culture before the arrival of the Europeans.  O'Brien's book contains photos of former cannibals who were still living at the time he was there.  In addition, the pre-European peoples were not free from disease, elephantiasis being inidigenous to the South Pacific.  There were also non-paradisical things such as large very poisonous centipedes.  The movie is a rather childish paradise-lost story, and not at all faithful to the book.However, the photography in the movie is worth the purchase: on-location photos of a South Pacific still in relative isolation.  The print was sometimes off, being brown instead of black and white, but still very, very watchable.  It is also an important film in the history of silent movies and for those who appreciate this well worth watching.
summary: Inaccurate but interesting early on-location photography
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is an extraordinary film that is undeservedly underrated. Our hero Monte Blue despises the exploitation of the natives in the South Seas and dedicates himself to preserving the lifestyle he does not take for granted. A somewhat radical socially conscious film. Marvellous cinematography and I found it rewarding to watch this film while consulting director's W.S. "Woody" Van Dyke's published account of its making.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "White Shadows in the South Seas" is a 1928 silent film very loosely based on the 1919 novel of the same name by Frederick O'Brien. It was directed by Woody van Dyke and has the distinction of being the first MGM film released with a prerecorded soundtrack.Woody van Dyke (1889-1943) started out as an assistant director on the film but when documentary maker Robert Flaherty ("Nanook of the North") walked out, van Dyke got his chance to take the helm. (FWIW - Flaherty  helped make "Tabu" in 1931, also filmed in Polynesia and with large amounts of on location scenes showing local customs. Even though talkies were in vogue, "Tabu" was a silent film.)Van Dyke is best known for his "Thin Man" films, for which he received an Oscar nomination in 1935, he also received a nomination for "San Francisco" (1936) and directed Nelson Eddy and Jeanette Macdonald in 6 of their films. Van Dyke enjoyed exotic locations and made such films as "Heart of the Yukon" (1927), "Eskimo" (1933), "Northwest Passage" (1940) and "Cairo" (1942). His nickname was "one take" because he liked to get the shot in one take, which made him invaluable to MGM from a cost POV.The beautiful photography is courtesy of Clyde De Vinna (1890-1953) who began work in 1915 ("The 3 Musketeers") and was famous for his on location shots with van Dyke - "Eskimo" (1933), "Trader Horn" (1931), etc.. For this film he won an Oscar. He worked on several Tarzan films in the 30s and 40s and eventually ended up in TV in the 50s ("The Roy Rogers Show").Not only is the photography beautiful there are several underwater sequences that are very advanced for that time.Monte Blue (1887-1963) stars as a drunken physician who is washed ashore on a beautiful island. Blue was a leading man in romantic films in the silent era. He's probably best remembered today as the sheriff in "Key Largo" (1948).His romantic interest is Mexican-German Raquel Torres (1908-87) who is probably most famous for her role as Vera Marcal, the femme fatale from "Duck Soup" (1933). This was her film debut.Robert Anderson (1890-1963) plays the villain who uses the natives to find pearls. Anderson had worked with Blue and van Dyke in D.W. Griffith's "Intolerance" (1916). This was his last featured role, though he had small parts in some early talkies ("Rasputin and the Empress", "Treasure Island").Otherwise most of the players are natives.The film suffers from age and there are several different sequences in various colors. The soundtrack is not crisp but you can hear the prerecorded music and some occasional sound effects including whistles, bird calls, and even some words. For 1928 this was a "talkie".The theme of the film is the purity of the native and the degeneracy of the white man. It was a common theme at the end of the 19th Century and was reflected in books, art, and the creation of the "back to nature" movement.Bottom line - a film that is important as a portrait of life in Tahiti in the early 20th Century and a look at film at the transition between silent and talking films.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I BOUGHT THIS MOVIE BECAUSE OF THE TERRIFIC BOOK BY FREDRICK OBRIAN WHICH INSPIRED THE MOVIE. THE DVD'S ARE MADE INDIVIDUALLY WHEN YOU ORDER THEM AND I HAD TO BUY IT 3 TIMES BEFORE I FINALY GOT A DISC THAT WOULD PLAY ON MY SONY BLUE RAY.BE WARNED, THE PACKAGE STATES IT WILL PROBABLY NOT PLAY ON A COMPUTER. EVEN WITH THE VOLUME ON MINIMUM THE MOVIE WAS TOO LOUD AND THIS IS FOR A PERSON WHO IS ALWAYS TOLD BY MY SPOUSE AND SON THAT I KEEP THE TV TOO LOUD. You could blow out your speakers.White Shadows in the South SeasTHE FANTASTIC BOOK  BY O'BRIAN IS SET IN THE MARQUESAS AND IT IS NOT A NOVEL AS REPORTED IN WIKIPEDIA BUT RATHER A NON FICTION TRAVEL BOOK. IMAGINE MY SURPRISE WHEN IT WAS FILMED IN TAHITI!!! I WANTED TO SEE THE NATIVES FROM THE MARQUESAS. IT WAS FILMED IN 1927 AND RELEASED IN '28.  IN THE BOOK "MANUIOTA'A: JOURNAL OF A VOYAGE TO THE MARQUESAS ISLANDS" BY ARCHIOLOGIST ROBERT C SUGGS AND  AUTHOR BURGI LICHENSTEIN THEY REPORT THAT THE LAST DOCUMENTED CASE OF CANNIBALISM IN THE MARQUESAS WAS IN THE 1920'S AND MAYBE THE PRODUCERS WERE AFRAID OF BEING EATEN.( IT IS A GREAT BOOK AND SHOULD BE READ BY ANYONE INTERESTED IN THE MARQUESAS) THE MOVIE  HAS NOTHING TO DO WITH O'BRIAN'S BOOK EXCEPT THE TITLE. THE MOVIManuiota'a: Journal of a Voyage to the Marquesas IslandsE WON A WELL DESERVED ACADEMY AWARD FOR BEST CINEMATOGRAPHY. THE MOVIE IS CRISP AND CLEAN THROUGHOUT WITH AMAZING UNDERWATER SCEENS THAT HOLD UP TO TODAYS STANDARDS, LET ALONE 1927 TECHNOLOGY. THE FEMALE LEAD IS NOT FROM TAHITI BUT HERMOSILLO, MEXICO. SO MUCH FOR SEEING POLYNESIANS. IT WAS THE FIRST MOVIE FROM MGM WITH A SOUNDTRACK BUT IT IS REALLY A SILENT FILM WITH THE DIALOGUE WRITTEN AS WITH THE TYPICAL SILENT FILMS. NOT RECOMMENDED FOR ANYONE WHO LOVED O'BRIANS BOOK BUT IT IS A WELL MADE MOVIE.
Title: N/A

reviewText: White Shadows in the South Seas was MGM's first sound film; although the sound we hear today seems unremarkable it must have really impressed audiences when it was first released! True, we don't hear very many words; the character of Matthew Lloyd shouts out "Hello!" three or four times and there's some sad moaning when someone dies--but that was revolutionary for its day. Those underwater scenes were filmed using state of the art technology at the time and they still look good! The acting is superlative and the choreography is as good as that fine cinematography. The musical score enhances the film, too.  The quality of the print could have been somewhat better but the story is so poignant and memorable that I really liked the film anyway.When the action starts, we meet the villain you will just love to hate, Sebastian (Robert Anderson), who with his cronies is destroying the native customs of the South Seas Marquesa islands as he pushes the natives ever further to find pearls for him. The natives don't know that the pearls have any value; in more than one scene Sebastian gives a native a cheap watch (probably from a five and dime cent store in the States) in exchange for a good sized, perfectly shaped pearl. Indeed, the natives have been so driven by the white man's greed and exploitation that they literally risk their lives looking for pearls. They die swimming in shark infested waters, get themselves stuck underwater in powerful clams, suffer collapsed lungs and endure bursting blood vessels because of the change in pressure between the underwater world and the world above water! The only white man on the island who objects to this is the mysteriously ruined Dr. Matthew Lloyd (Monte Blue); Matthew objects vehemently to Sebastian's evil and the dishonesty of the other white men.Sebastian plans more; he tricks Matthew into being taken away by force on a ship bound for goodness knows where. However, the boat soon runs into a huge, life threatening storm; everyone onboard dies except for Matthew. Matthew is swept onto the shore of another island, this one untouched by the white man's greed.It's paradise there and the natives think Matthew is a God simply because he is white! They welcome Matthew and it isn't long before he marries Fayaway (Raquel Torres), the virgin bride of the tribe. The tribe greatly admires the medical skill of the "white God" who is now renamed Matta Loa.Matta Loa is happy--for a while, at least. Matthew is, of course, not a God. He is a man; a human being who ultimately surrenders to his own greed for the native's pearls on that island--pearls they throw away while making fishhooks! When Matta Loa impulsively makes a fire to alert a passing ship to take him away from the island and what really counts in life, an chain of unexpected events is started...There's plenty more to the plot but I'll stop to avoid giving away spoilers; I want you to watch and enjoy the film as much as I did! Suffice it to say that the rest of the film shows how everything plays out.Look also for good performances by Renee Bush as Lucy and Napua as a native boy.White Shadows in the South Seas is a must-have for fans of the actors in it and anyone who appreciates excellent early sound film with superb cinematography. People who like drama with romantic themes will also like this film.
Title: N/A
